sentence: Procter & Gamble stock rose early Tuesday, as the household products maker’s fiscal first-quarter earnings came in ahead of expectations, and the company boosted its forecast for the full year.
P&G (ticker: PG) said it earned $1.63 a share on revenue that rose 9% to $19.3 billion.
Analysts were looking for per-share earnings of $1.42 on revenue of $18.4 billion.
The company’s home-care unit, which includes its cleaning products like Mr. Clean and Swiffer, was the standout.
It saw sales climb 30%, while the fabric and home-care brands division’s organic sales increased 14%.
Recent consumer data show that shoppers are willing to pay for premium brands over private label ones during the Covid-19 pandemic.
Elsewhere, its beauty segment’s organic sales rose 7%, while its grooming business generated a 6% rise in organic sales.
That metric rose 12% at its health-care segment, and 4% at its baby and family care division.
Total organic sales climbed 9% in the quarter, while gross margins increased 170 basis points year over year.
The company returned $4 billion of cash to shareholders evenly split between dividend and stock repurchases.
P&G anticipates paying $8 billion in dividends in fiscal 2021 and boosted its outlook for buybacks to $7 billion to $9 billion for the year, up from a prior range of $6 billion to $8 billion.
For the full year, P&G raised its EPS growth outlook to 5% to 8% (up from 3% to 7%) or $5.38 to $5.53 a share, compared with the $5.43 consensus estimate.
It sees organic sales rising 4% to 5%, up from its previous estimates of 2% to 4% growth.
P&G stock was up 1.4% to $1.44 in recent trading, building on the stock’s nearly 14% year-to-date rise.
The quarter was strong all around, with strength across segments and organic sales up from the previous quarter.
P&G has long excelled in delivering organic growth, a key metric for consumer products companies, and it has been steadily expanding during the pandemic.

Moreover, the company’s confidence in issuing full-year guidance and returning more cash to shareholders is a welcome move, especially when not all companies have reinstated their forecasts and their dividends.
